Home-based learning: With schools closed, parents or guardians could take on the role of educators and provide structured learning activities in the comfort of their own homes. This could include one-on-one instruction, group activities, and hands-on learning experiences tailored to each child's needs and abilities. Confidence score: 0.8

Community-led learning centers: Neighborhoods could come together to create community-led learning centers where children can access educational resources, including books, computers, and educational materials. Volunteers could serve as teachers, mentors, and support staff, providing a safe and engaging learning environment. Confidence score: 0.9

Virtual learning platforms: With the help of technology, virtual learning platforms could be created to provide online educational resources and interactive learning experiences. This could include virtual classrooms, video lessons, and virtual field trips, allowing children to continue their education remotely. Confidence score: 0.9

Mobile learning units: Mobile learning units could be established to travel to different communities, providing educational resources and learning opportunities to children in underserved areas. These units could be equipped with educational materials, computers, and other necessary tools to provide a comprehensive learning experience. Confidence score: 0.8
